questions.text: A 47-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital after experiencing nausea and vomiting for about 2 days followed by severe muscle weakness and neurological symptoms including ptosis and dysphagia. She told the resident doctor on duty that she had dinner in a restaurant the evening before the symptoms began. Her lab tests were positive for Clostridium botulinum. What could be the basis of muscle weakness in this case?

options.label: A
options.text: Blocked the reuptake of neurotransmitter into the presynaptic nerve terminal.

options.label: B
options.text: Bound irreversibly to the receptors on the postsynaptic membrane.

options.label: C
options.text: Prevented the release of acetylcholine from the nerve terminal.

options.label: D
options.text: Exerted its adverse effects by a direct action on the skeletal muscle.

questions.correct_answer: C. Prevented the release of acetylcholine from the nerve terminal.
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Prevented the release of acetylcholine from the nerve terminal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Botulinum toxin prevents the release of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction by inhibiting SNARE proteins, leading to muscle weakness and flaccid paralysis.

questions.text: Assume that excess blood is transfused into a patient whose arterial baroreceptors are non-functional and whose blood pressure increases from 100 to 150 mm Hg. Then, assume that the same volume of blood is infused into the same patient under conditions in which his arterial baroreceptors are functioning normally, and blood pressure increases from 100 to 125 mm Hg. What is the approximate feedback "gain" of the arterial baroreceptors in this patient when they are functioning normally?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) -1.0

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The gain of the baroreceptor system is calculated as the ratio of correction to error. In a negative feedback system like the baroreceptor reflex, this gain is typically negative, indicating opposition to the original disturbance. In this case, the gain is -1.0 .
  • ➤ -1.0

questions.text: Preload is the stretching of the cardiac muscle fibers at the end of diastole, just before contraction. It is due to an increase in ventricular pressure caused by the filling of blood during diastole. An image is provided that further supplements the findings stated above. These are expressions of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Frank-Starling’s law

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Frank-Starling’s law explains that increased preload (end-diastolic volume) leads to increased stroke volume due to enhanced muscle fiber stretching and increased force of contraction within physiological limits.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male is brought to the emergency department with complaints of right-sided weakness and jargon speech. A CT brain was ordered to rule out hemorrhagic stroke. On neurological examination, there is normal object recognition but loss of comprehension. Which of the following areas is affected?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Superior temporal gyrus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Damage to the superior temporal gyrus, particularly Wernicke’s area, results in fluent but nonsensical speech (jargon speech) and loss of comprehension, typical of Wernicke's aphasia.

questions.text: Which of the following statements are incorrect about vasopressin?

options.label: A

options.label: B
options.text: Concentration of circulating blood vasopressin after severe hemorrhage can increase enough to attenuate reductions in arterial pressure markedly.

questions.text: A 55-year-old smoker having difficulty in breathing was diagnosed with pulmonary fibrosis and has an oxygen saturation of 89%. The cause of this reduced saturation is a defect in which mechanism?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Simple diffusion

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diffusion of gases, such as oxygen and carbon dioxide, across the alveolar membrane occurs via simple diffusion , which is impaired in conditions like pulmonary fibrosis, leading to reduced oxygen saturation.
  • ➤ simple diffusion

questions.text: True statement regarding the given nerve action potential curve is?

options.text: At point E, the nerve is more excitable

options.label: C

questions.text: Identify the type of transport across the cell membrane represented below?

Ans. B) Facilitated diffusion

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A preterm baby who was delivered at 28 weeks developed respiratory distress syndrome. Which of the following is true about surface tension and compliance in this baby?

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In preterm babies with respiratory distress syndrome, surface tension increases due to a lack of surfactant, and lung compliance decreases, making it harder for the lungs to expand.

questions.text: A patient met with a road traffic accident and developed a cervical spine injury. The fracture fragment had pierced the lateral aspect of the dorsal column tract. Which of the following findings is seen in this patient?

questions.text: The relaxation of the intestinal segment distal to the segment with the bolus of food during peristalsis is because of?

questions.text: All of the following increase gastric acid secretion except:

Ans. D) Serotonin

  • ➤ gastrin

questions.text: The stroke volume depends on end-diastolic volume. This is best represented as?

questions.text: A team of climbers is being briefed about the physiological changes that occur in the body at high altitudes. Which of the following is not a typical physiological response seen in individuals at high altitudes?

  • ➤ not
  • ➤ hyperventilation

questions.text: A patient experiences bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea following the administration of intravenous irritants during a medical procedure. These symptoms are suggestive of a specific reflex response. Which one of the following reflexes is most likely being represented in this scenario?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Bezold-Jarisch reflex

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Bezold-Jarisch reflex is characterized by bradycardia, hypotension, and apnea, usually triggered by intravenous irritants or certain medical procedures, and is mediated through excessive vagal activation.
  • ➤ Bezold-Jarisch reflex

  • ➤ Expiratory Reserve Volume (C)

questions.text: Kinesin, dynein and myosin proteins are an example of:

  • ➤ myosin
  • ➤ transport proteins

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient presents with a history of progressive weakness and sensory loss in the limbs. Nerve conduction studies indicate a demyelinating pattern. Genetic testing reveals a mutation in the gene producing subunits of gap junctions. These clinical and genetic findings point towards Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease (CMT). Which subunits of the cellular structures are impacted by the genetic mutation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Connexons

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Connexons are the subunits of gap junctions , and mutations in the genes encoding connexin proteins can lead to disorders like Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease , characterized by impaired nerve conduction and demyelination.
  • ➤ Connexons
  • ➤ gap junctions
  • ➤ Charcot-Marie-Tooth disease

questions.text: A cardiologist is evaluating a 45-year-old patient who presents with an irregular heart rhythm. options.label: C
options.text: Combined opening of sodium and calcium channels (Na⁺ & Ca²⁺)

questions.explanation:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the SA node , phase zero of the action potential is driven by the opening of voltage-gated calcium channels , leading to a slower depolarization compared to other cardiac tissues, which rely on sodium influx.

  • ➤ phase zero
  • ➤ voltage-gated calcium channels

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient is diagnosed with hypercalcemia. The medical team is evaluating how this condition affects the patient's membrane excitability. Which of the following best describes the impact of hypercalcemia on membrane excitability?

options.label: C
options.text: Hypercalcemia has no effect on membrane excitability.

options.label: D
options.text: Hypercalcemia leads to unpredictable changes in membrane excitability.

questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hypercalcemia reduces membrane excitability.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Hypercalcemia reduces membrane excitability by decreasing sodium permeability , which stabilizes the membrane and makes it less likely to depolarize in response to stimuli.
  • ➤ Hypercalcemia
  • ➤ decreasing sodium permeability

  • ➤ C fibers
  • ➤ temperature and pain sensations

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman with a history of progressive muscle weakness undergoes a series of diagnostic tests including an electromyography. questions.text: A 22-year-old gymnast presents to the sports medicine clinic with complaints of muscle cramps and prolonged soreness following her training sessions. questions.text: All of the following are true in Syndrome of Inappropriate Antidiuretic Hormone secretion (SIADH) except:

options.label: B
options.text: Urine Na+ concentration < 20 mmol/L with normal salt intake

questions.correct_answer: B. Urine Na+ concentration < 20 mmol/L with normal salt intake
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Urine Na+ concentration < 20 mmol/L with normal salt intake

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In SIADH, patients exhibit euvolemic hyponatremia with high urine sodium concentration (>20 mmol/L) and high urine osmolarity (>100 mOsm/L). Serum osmolarity is typically low (<275 mOsm/L).
  • ➤ euvolemic hyponatremia
  • ➤ high urine sodium
  • ➤ high urine osmolarity
  • ➤ low

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman suffering from a common cold visited the hospital with complaints of vomiting for three days and extreme weakness. Her examination and lab findings are as follows: Blood pressure : 90/60 mmHg Pulse : 110/min Respiratory rate : 10/min Blood pH : 7.6 Plasma bicarbonate : 30 mEq/L PCO2 : 45 mmHg What is the patient's current acid-base status, and which hormones are involved?

options.label: B
options.text: Metabolic alkalosis , aldosterone and angiotensin II

options.label: C
options.text: Respiratory acidosis , aldosterone and angiotensin II

questions.correct_answer: B. Metabolic alkalosis , aldosterone and angiotensin II
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Metabolic alkalosis, aldosterone, and angiotensin II

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Metabolic alkalosis is commonly caused by vomiting, leading to the loss of hydrogen ions (stomach acid) and resulting in elevated bicarbonate levels. Aldosterone and angiotensin II are key hormones involved in this process, particularly through their effects on the kidneys and the renin-angiotensin-aldosterone system.

questions.text: A 77-year-old man comes to the physician because of swelling in his legs and feet for the past 6 months. He has a 40-year history of alcoholism and a 5-year history of hepatic disease. Physical examination reveals ascites and edema of the lower extremities. A decrease in which of the following is most likely promoting edema formation in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Plasma colloid oncotic pressure

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Plasma colloid oncotic pressure , largely maintained by albumin, is essential for retaining fluid within the blood vessels. Decreased plasma oncotic pressure, often due to liver dysfunction, is a major contributor to edema and ascites .
  • ➤ Plasma colloid oncotic pressure
  • ➤ edema
  • ➤ ascites

questions.text: A 50-year-old male presents to the clinic with symptoms of increased hand and foot size, coarsening facial features, and recent onset of diabetes mellitus. His IGF-1 levels are elevated. Which of the following is most likely acting as a second messenger in the pathophysiology of this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Calcium

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Calcium acts as a crucial second messenger in many cellular signaling pathways, including those mediated by IGF-1 . In conditions like acromegaly , elevated IGF-1 levels lead to increased intracellular calcium, which drives tissue growth and contributes to the clinical manifestations of the disease.
  • ➤ Calcium
  • ➤ IGF-1
  • ➤ acromegaly

questions.text: Which of the following will increase the glomerular filtration rate (GFR)?

options.label: A
options.text: Afferent arteriolar constriction, efferent arteriolar dilation

options.label: B
options.text: Afferent arteriolar dilation, efferent arteriolar constriction

options.label: C
options.text: Afferent arteriolar constriction, efferent arteriolar constriction

options.label: D
options.text: Afferent arteriolar dilation, efferent arteriolar dilation

questions.correct_answer: B. Afferent arteriolar dilation, efferent arteriolar constriction
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Afferent arteriolar dilation, efferent arteriolar constriction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Afferent arteriolar dilation combined with efferent arteriolar constriction increases glomerular filtration rate (GFR) by elevating the hydrostatic pressure within the glomerulus.
  • ➤ Afferent arteriolar dilation
  • ➤ efferent arteriolar constriction
  • ➤ glomerular filtration rate (GFR)

questions.text: In a 70-year-old male, a substance was used to measure the renal clearance. The urine concentration of this substance was 120 mg/mL, the plasma concentration was 40 mg/mL, and the urinary flow was 20 mL/min. Calculate the clearance of this substance.
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 60 mL/min

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The renal clearance of a substance can be calculated using the formula C=U×VPC = \frac{U \times V}{P}C=PU×V​, where U is the urine concentration, V is the urine flow rate, and P is the plasma concentration.
  • ➤ renal clearance

questions.text: Which of the following substances has the lowest renal clearance rate?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Urea

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Among urea, creatinine, and inulin, urea has the lowest renal clearance due to its significant reabsorption in the kidney.
  • ➤ urea
  • ➤ lowest renal clearance

questions.text: A nephrologist is evaluating the glomerular filtration properties of a patient with suspected alteration in the glomerular basement membrane charge. A graph is presented showing the relative filterability of variously charged molecules across the glomerular filtration membrane. Given the graph, which statement accurately describes the filtration of molecules based on their charge?

options.label: A
options.text: Polycationic and polyanionic dextran is filtered more readily than neutral dextran.

options.label: B
options.text: Neutral dextran is filtered more readily than polyanionic dextran.

options.label: C
options.text: Polyanionic dextran has the highest filterability across the glomerular membrane.

options.label: D
options.text: Polycationic and polyanionic dextran have similar filterability at larger molecular radii.

questions.correct_answer: B. Neutral dextran is filtered more readily than polyanionic dextran.
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Neutral dextran is filtered more readily than polyanionic dextran.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neutral dextran is filtered more readily than polyanionic dextran across the glomerular filtration membrane due to the negative charge on the glomerular basement membrane, which repels negatively charged molecules.
  • ➤ Neutral dextran is filtered more readily than polyanionic dextran

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of autonomic dysfunction presents with episodes of dizziness and fluctuating blood pressure readings. During his evaluation, a series of tests are conducted to assess the relationship between his mean arterial BP and plasma vasopressin levels. Which graph best represents the physiological relationship between mean arterial BP and plasma vasopressin concentration? Abscissa= mean arterial BP ; Ordinate= plasma vasopressin
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Graph C

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The relationship between mean arterial pressure (MAP) and plasma vasopressin is inverse. When MAP decreases, plasma vasopressin increases, and when MAP increases, vasopressin decreases.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male with chronic kidney disease is being evaluated for electrolyte imbalances. The nephrologist is explaining the importance of different renal transport mechanisms in the loop of Henle, especially concerning the resorption of divalent ions such as calcium and magnesium. Which mechanism in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle is primarily responsible for the resorption of these divalent ions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Paracellular transport

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Calcium and magnesium reabsorption in the thick ascending limb of the loop of Henle occurs primarily via paracellular transport , driven by the positive voltage gradient created by sodium, potassium, and chloride reabsorption.
  • ➤ paracellular transport

questions.text: A urologist is reviewing a cystometrogram of a patient who complains of urinary difficulties. The graph is used to understand the relationship between bladder pressure and volume during the filling and voiding phases. Which of the following statements is true regarding the given cystometrogram below?

options.label: A
options.text: Segment I represents the compliance phase of the bladder.

options.label: B
options.text: Segment II represents the phase of involuntary bladder contractions.

options.label: C
options.text: Micturition typically occurs at the end of segment III.

options.label: D
options.text: The dotted line in segment IV indicates the point of micturition.

questions.correct_answer: C. Micturition typically occurs at the end of segment III.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Micturition typically occurs at the end of segment III of the cystometrogram, where the bladder reaches its maximum capacity and pressure starts to rise, signaling the need for urination.
  • ➤ segment III

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a history of hypertension presents with edema (fluid retention) and elevated blood pressure. The patient's healthcare provider suspects activation of the renin-angiotensin system (RAS). Which of the following effects of RAS stimulation is most likely contributing to the patient's symptoms, and what hormonal changes would be expected? Water loss Sodium retention Expansion of ECF Increased aldosterone levels
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 2, 3, 4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Activation of the Renin-Angiotensin System (RAS) causes sodium retention, expansion of the extracellular fluid, and increased aldosterone levels, which together contribute to hypertension and fluid retention.

questions.text: A portion of animal’s intestine is fixed in the Dales chamber. After infusing a drug changes are seen in intestinal contractility as depicted in the graph. Which of the following agent resembles the effect?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Adrenaline

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Adrenaline reduces intestinal motility by activating beta-2 adrenergic receptors, leading to the relaxation of smooth muscle.

questions.text: A 16 months old male child was admitted in the pediatric ward with a history of loose stools for the past 2 weeks and poor weight gain since birth. On detailed evaluation, the child was diagnosed to have cystic fibrosis. Which of the following channels in the gastrointestinal tract are expected to be affected in this child?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Chloride channels

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cystic fibrosis is primarily caused by defective chloride channels due to mutations in the CFTR gene, leading to thick mucus production, poor digestion, and weight gain issues.

questions.text: A 40-year-old patient presents with recurrent episodes of crampy abdominal pain, diarrhea, and urgency to defecate. These symptoms are exacerbated after meals and are accompanied by increased bowel movements. Further evaluation suggests a motility disorder affecting the GIT. Which specific part of GIT is associated with massive propulsive wave of contractions?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Colon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mass movements in the colon are responsible for the massive propulsive waves of contraction that often occur after meals, moving contents toward the rectum and facilitating defecation, commonly linked to the gastrocolic reflex .
  • ➤ Mass movements
  • ➤ colon
  • ➤ massive propulsive waves of contraction
  • ➤ gastrocolic reflex

questions.text: Mahima, a 30-year-old woman, visited her gastroenterologist with complaints of recurring stomach discomfort, bloating, and occasional heartburn after meals. Her symptoms seemed to worsen when she consumed certain types of foods. The gastroenterologist suspected that her symptoms could be linked to gastric acid secretion, a crucial aspect of digestive function. Which of the following statements are true about gastric acid secretion and its implications for Mahima 's symptoms?" Parietal cell derived Proton pumps Passive transport Potassium channels involved
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 1,  2,  4

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gastric acid secretion is derived from parietal cells , involves active transport via proton pumps , and potassium channels are essential for the cycling of K+ ions to maintain the function of these pumps. This process is not passive but an energy-dependent mechanism, contributing to digestive issues such as those seen in Mahima's case.
  • ➤ derived from parietal cells
  • ➤ active transport via proton pumps
  • ➤ potassium channels

questions.text: A 56-year old female came to the medicine department with the clinical features of breathlessness, fatigue and palpitations. On evaluation, she was found to have vitamin B 12 deficiency due to an intestinal pathology. Which part of the intestine is mainly involved in the absorption of this vitamin?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Ileum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B12 is absorbed in the terminal ileum after binding to intrinsic factor , and any pathology affecting the ileum can lead to vitamin B12 deficiency.
  • ➤ terminal ileum
  • ➤ intrinsic factor

questions.text: A 65-year-old man is admitted to the hospital with a severe case of diarrhea that has lasted for several days. He is experiencing dehydration and electrolyte imbalances. Upon examination, his physician suspects that the primary site of fluid and electrolyte absorption is compromised. Which part of the gastrointestinal tract is primarily responsible for the absorption of water and electrolytes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Colon

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The colon is the main site for water and electrolyte absorption in the gastrointestinal tract. Pathologies affecting the colon, such as prolonged diarrhea, can lead to dehydration and electrolyte imbalances.
  • ➤ colon
  • ➤ water
  • ➤ electrolyte

questions.text: In a 57 year old patient with chronic acid reflux and peptic ulcer symptoms, which type of gastric mucosal cells is primarily responsible for secreting a substance that stimulates the production of hydrochloric acid in the stomach, potentially contributing to the patient's digestive issues?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) G cells

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ G cells release gastrin , which is the key hormone responsible for stimulating the secretion of hydrochloric acid (HCl) by the parietal cells in the stomach, contributing to acid-related digestive issues like peptic ulcers and acid reflux.
  • ➤ G cells
  • ➤ gastrin
  • ➤ hydrochloric acid (HCl)
